abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show a satisfactory
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. The project's
            public-private partnership approach was very innovative at
            the time the project was designed. Although such
            partnerships are now more common, they are not always
            successfully implemented. Yet, the success of this operation
            stems from: adhering to a supply-chain approach in
            introducing new and diversified product-lines; implementing
            a participatory approach with all beneficiaries in the
            design, procurement, and implementation; emphasizing a total
            quality control system; initiating the creation of a private
            foundation endowed with the project's assets; and,
            creating a valuable "soft asset." Important
            lessons were drawn from the application of these ideas: 1)
            Accumulation of soft assets is critical for triggering
            growth and private sector investment: this project provides
            a notable exception, not only in the effectiveness of the
            institutional learning that it triggered, but also in the
            momentum generated for continued institutional innovation.
            The project was able to double exports by successfully
            investing in soft assets that changed the perception (both
            internally and externally) of the Senegalese horticultural
            sector, to that of a serious competitor/contender on the
            horticultural export scene, thereby leveraging additional
            outside private investment. 2) Business savvy international
            technical assistance is an effective means of providing the
            hands-on demonstration effects necessary to shift
            institutional/business paradigms: demonstration effects were
            provided not only for new crops and cropping systems but
            also, and more importantly, they tested new marketing
            methods and pricing protocols which allowed producers and
            marketers to realize attractive profits. 3) A bottom-up,
            versus top-down, inclusive approach is key for building
            capacity and assuring sustainability: it led to substantial
            institutional development, eventual buy-in for the design of
            the innovative export infrastructure facilities, and
            agreement over the creation of a Foundation representing the
            interests of all actors. Further lessons address the
            infrastructure investment process, and the shortness of the
            standard four-five year credit implementation time frame,
            suggesting it is too short to build sustainable
            institutional capacity.

5084220.trustfund:
TF035493-SENEGAL - PILOT AGRICULTURAL
            EXPORT PROMOTION PROJECT,TF038913-SENEGAL - AGRICULTURAL EXPORT PROMOTION

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Agricultural
            Export Promotion Project are to diversify and develop
            private agricultural exports, a core objective of
            Senegal's export-led growth strategy. The project has
            three components: 1) export promotion and diversification
            activities including a) assisting Senegalese
            producers/exporters in market research, customer
            identification, meeting quality requirements, trial
            shipments, obtaining pre-export finance and developing
            maritime agricultural export crops; b) product development
            and processing, and quality control via targeted adaptive
            research; and c) establishment of business partnerships
            between local exporters and foreign businesses, and
            assistance in identifying regional and overseas niches; 2)
            strengthening of existing private producers/exporters'
            professional organizations, encouraging the creation of
            farmers' associations where needed, and setting up a
            central referral/data information service as well as
            providing management and legal advice; and 3) upgrading of
            export facilities at the airport of Dakar to preserve
            perishable products in transit; and 4) project management.

441714.trustfund:
TF038913-SENEGAL - AGRICULTURAL EXPORT PROMOTION,TF035637-AFRICA REGION - POVERTY
            NOTE-POVERTY UPDATE IN RWANDA AND BURINDI,TF035493-SENEGAL - PILOT AGRICULTURAL
            EXPORT PROMOTION PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Agricultural Export Promotion
            Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Agricultural Export Promotion Project in Senegal, which
            assists farmers in both traditional and non-traditional crop
            production and export; supports producers to develop high
            value-added crops; and strengthens farmers organizations.
            Negative impacts on the vegetal cover, the soil, water, and
            the affected population will lead to reduced land
            productivity, water-related diseases--malaria and
            bilharzia--droughts, salinization, water contamination from
            misuse and over-use of fertilizers and pesticides, and soil
            erosion. Traffic accidents, noise due to the increased load
            of vehicles and airplanes transportation, gas emissions, and
            effluents will also occur. Mitigation includes afforestation
            efforts combined with irrigation development and an
            information campaign for soil, water, and biomass
            conservation. Hygiene education and community management and
            awareness will be developed to ensure better water supply
            and sanitation services, and to reduce disease. Preserving
            traditional floral species, setting aside protected areas,
            and introducing foreign species compatible with farm crops
            will arrest deforestation. Fuel conservation will discourage
            stripping trees. Extension services will educate farmers
            about soil conditions and composting to mitigate soil
            degradation. Installing a piezometer to control lowering
            groundwater and measuring water quality, designing
            activities to prevent floods, and regulating use will help
            manage water resources.
